Elliotte Harold wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  > Elliotte, I don't understand this article.
>  >
>  > You say that there was a bug in this code:
>  >
>  > private void _setType(Type type) {
>  > this.type = type;
>  > }
>  >
>  > This bug caused a NullPointerException to occur. I don't see how that's
>  > possible, since "this" cannot be null.
> 
> Either you misread or I miswrote the article (or both). The bug was not
> that a NullPointerException was thrown. The bug was that a
> NullPointerException was *not* thrown when the client passed in null to
> the public API.

Cool. I definitely misunderstood that, then, although you might share 
the blame. :)

> Once pointed out, it was obviously a bug. XOM doesn't allow most things
> to be null, and indeed promises they aren't. Prior to writing the test,
> I devised an incorrect solution to the problem that put the null check
> in the wrong place (the non-public method). Writing the test suddenly
> made it apparent that my solution was wrong, and that I needed to put
> the null-check elsewhere (the public method). Had I not written the test
> before fixing the bug, I likely would not have noticed this.

Absolutely. That I both get and love.

> TDD isn't just about testing. It's also about helping you look at your
> own code from a different angle. Sometimes that helps you see things you
> wouldn't otherwise notice.

I couldn't agree more! Yet another reason to write tests.
